Hi Paul,

Any idea of this kodachi's actual dimensions, blade and grip leng=
th
etc.? 

Yours

Dean


In message <20041003193628.84747.qmail@...=
il.ukl.yahoo.com>,
Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> writes
>    HI
>
> =
   I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once belonged
>    to a very fa=
moius member of the Yagyu family dated
>    about 1600. it has just been re=
polished and is about
>    to be submitted for new papers elevating it to a=

>    national treasure I will ask if I can post the pic I
>    was sent
>
=
>    paul
>
>
>    --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
>   =
 ---------------------------------
>    Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very=
 interested. This
>    very interesting.
>
>    Thanks, it helps a lot!
>
>=
    Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
>    HI
>
>    here is a br=
ief description. I wont go into details to
>    much as I assume you are no=
t a member of either ryu.
>
>    kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 =
kata for the
>    use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to say
>  =
  there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote gata,
>    but i have se=
en a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura gata
>    were listed in it.
>
>    In =
each one the attacker will come at you with a
>    katana and he is trying =
to cut across at your torso.
>    The reason for this is you are moving aro=
und him and
>    you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
>    maki=
ng him attack the area you choose. Once he does in
>    all three you rush =
in fast and thrust the kodachi into
>    him.
>
>    In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu =
(HYR), I have not studied. I
>    have been shown the kata once and I have =
them on
>    video. therefore cant describe them properly.
>
>    There are=
 five omote kata and I am told maybe some ura
>    gata (which I have not s=
een or know of). They like the
>    Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a fe=
w slashing such
>    as to the neck or torso.
>
>    The HYR tend to sink l=
ower in kamae than the KSDR.
>
>    However there is a historical link betw=
een the two
>    ryu.
>
>    Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden H=
appo
>    Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main branch
>    of that=
 is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This all
>    originates from the Kuki f=
amily who are today still
>    soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also h=
ead
>    priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni Onihei
>    was a =
shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with Takagi
>    Gennoshin from Takagi Y=
oshin ryu. together they
>    exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was=
 changed.
>    Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the early
>    =
1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
>    handed menkyo kaiden =
makimono for the Takagi Yoshin
>    ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were =
to be passed to
>    Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and Takamatsu
=
>    held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and kukishin
>    Ryu. sort ti=
me later Minaki sensei is handed menkyo
>    kaiden in the kakuno takagi ry=
u and from him him the
>    HYR is developed.
>
>    for more indepth info =
and lines history check out
>    these sites.
>
>    http://www.hontaiyoshi=
nryu.com/
>    http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
>    http://www.shinjin.co=
.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
>    http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.=
htm
>    http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm=A0 (my web site)
>
>    paul
>=

>
>
>    --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
>    --------=
-------------------------
>    what's the difference between the Kukishinde=
n Ryu
>    Kodachi and the Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu Kodachi? This is
>    pretty =
interesting!
>
>    Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:Hi
>
>    wh=
at explaination would you like. I have studied
>    Kukishinden Ryu Kodachi=
 and been shown Hon Tai Yoshin
>    Ryu Kodachi.
>
>
>    Paul
>
>
>    ---=

>
>

------------
>    Ah, thank you. I'd like to get the explantion of the
>   =
 Ryu of the kodachi. *slaps self*
>
>    Richardson Paul <umaryu@....u=
k> wrote:Hi
>
>    in some cases the kodachi is also regarded as a
>    wak=
izashi.
>
>    Several Ryu still teach the use of the kodachi, two I
>    c=
an name are Kukishinden Ryu (3 kata) and HonTai
>    Yoshin Ryu (5 kata and=
 I think some ura gata).
>
>    paul
>

yahoo.com> wrote:
